title: On polynomially many queries to NP or QMA oracles
abstract:
Abstract
We study the complexity of problems solvable in deterministic polynomial time with access to an NPNP\mathrm{NP} or Quantum Merlin-Arthur (QMAQMA\mathrm{QMA})-oracle, such as PNPsuperscriptPNP\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}} and PQMAsuperscriptPQMA\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{QMA}}, respectively.
The former allows one to classify problems more finely than the Polynomial-Time Hierarchy (PHPH\mathrm{PH}), whereas the latter characterizes physically motivated problems such as Approximate Simulation (APX‚àíSIMAPXSIM\mathrm{APX\mathchar 45\relax{}SIM}) [Ambainis, CCC 2014].
In this area, a central role has been played by the classes PNP‚Äã[log]superscriptPNPdelimited-[]\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}[\log]} and PQMA‚Äã[log]superscriptPQMAdelimited-[]\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{QMA}[\log]}, defined identically to PNPsuperscriptPNP\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}} and PQMAsuperscriptPQMA\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{QMA}}, except that only logarithmically many oracle queries are allowed. Here, [Gottlob, FOCS 1993] showed that if the adaptive queries made by a PNPsuperscriptPNP\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}} machine have a ‚Äúquery graph‚Äù which is a tree, then this computation can be simulated in PNP‚Äã[log]superscriptPNPdelimited-[]\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}[\log]}.
In this work, we first show that for any verification class C‚àà{NP,MA,QCMA,QMA,QMA‚Äã(2),NEXP,QMAexp}ùê∂NPMAQCMAQMAQMA2NEXPsubscriptQMAexpC\in\{\mathrm{NP},\mathrm{MA},\mathrm{QCMA},\mathrm{QMA},\mathrm{QMA}(2),\allowbreak\mathrm{NEXP},\mathrm{QMA}_{\mathrm{exp}}\}, any PCsuperscriptPC\mathrm{P}^{\textup{C}} machine with a query graph of ‚Äúseparator number‚Äù sùë†s can be simulated using deterministic time exp‚Å°(s‚Äãlog‚Å°n)ùë†ùëõ\exp(s\log n) and s‚Äãlog‚Å°nùë†ùëõs\log n queries to a Cùê∂C-oracle.
When s‚ààO‚Äã(1)ùë†ùëÇ1s\in O(1) (which includes the case of O‚Äã(1)ùëÇ1O(1)-treewidth, and thus also of trees), this gives an upper bound of PC‚Äã[log]superscriptPCdelimited-[]\mathrm{P}^{\textup{C}[\log]}, and when s‚ààO‚Äã(logk‚Å°(n))ùë†ùëÇsuperscriptùëòùëõs\in O(\log^{k}(n)), this yields bound QPC‚Äã[logk+1]superscriptQPùê∂delimited-[]superscriptùëò1\mathrm{QP}^{C[\log^{k+1}]} (QPQP\mathrm{QP} meaning quasi-polynomial time).
We next show how to combine Gottlob‚Äôs ‚Äúadmissible-weighting function‚Äù framework with the ‚Äúflag-qubit‚Äù framework of [Watson, Bausch, Gharibian, 2020], obtaining a unified approach for embedding PCsuperscriptPC\mathrm{P}^{\textup{C}} computations directly into APX‚àíSIMAPXSIM\mathrm{APX\mathchar 45\relax{}SIM} instances in a black-box fashion.
Finally, we formalize a simple no-go statement about polynomials (c.f. [Krentel, STOC 1986]): Given a multi-linear polynomial pùëùp specified via an arithmetic circuit, if one can ‚Äúweakly compress‚Äù pùëùp so that its optimal value requires mùëöm bits to represent, then PNPsuperscriptPNP\mathrm{P}^{\mathrm{NP}} can be decided with only mùëöm queries to an NP-oracle.
